title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:1, who are we described as working together with?
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'We then, as workers together with him,' indicating we work with Him.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 6:2 say is the 'accepted time'?
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'now is the accepted time; behold, now is the day of salvation,' linking accepted time with salvation.

questions.question: What should ministers avoid according to 2 Corinthians 6:3?
questions.explanation: The verse advises giving no offence in anything to keep the ministry blameless.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned in 2 Corinthians 6:5 as a hardship endured?
questions.explanation: The verse mentions stripes, imprisonments, tumults, labours, watchings, and fastings but does not mention hunger specifically.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:6, what is one characteristic by which ministers approve themselves?
questions.explanation: Kindness is listed among the qualities by which ministers approve themselves.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:7, what do ministers wear on the right hand and on the left?
questions.explanation: The verse says ministers approve themselves by the armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left.

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 6:9 describes ministers as 'as unknown, and yet ______'.
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts being unknown and yet well known.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 6:10 say about those who have nothing?
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'as having nothing, and yet possessing all things.'

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:11, how do the Corinthians describe their mouth and heart?
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'our mouth is open unto you, our heart is enlarged.'

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 6:14 warns believers not to be unequally yoked with whom?
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Be ye not unequally yoked together with unbelievers.'

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:15, what has no concord with Christ?
questions.explanation: The verse asks, 'what concord hath Christ with Belial?'

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 6:16 states that believers are the temple of the living God.
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly says, 'ye are the temple of the living God.'

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 6:17 commands believers to come out from among them and be separate.
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'come out from among them, and be ye separate.'

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 6:18 promises God will be a Father and believers will be His sons and daughters.
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'I will be a Father unto you, and ye shall be my sons and daughters.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Corinthians 6:4: 'But in all things approving ourselves as the ministers of God, in much ______'.
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'in much patience, in afflictions, in necessities...'

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to remain patient during affliction. Based on 2 Corinthians 6, what biblical truth would you share about enduring hardships?
options: Endure hardships with patience as ministers of God, showing purity, knowledge, and love
Avoid hardships by seeking easier paths
Focus only on personal comfort and ignore afflictions
Hide your struggles from others to appear strong
questions.correctAnswer: Endure hardships with patience as ministers of God, showing purity, knowledge, and love
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:4-6 teaches us to approve ourselves as ministers of God through patience in afflictions, by purity, knowledge, longsuffering, kindness, and love unfeigned.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 6 encourage believers to handle their ministry to avoid blame?
options: By giving no offence in anything
By doing only what is easy
questions.correctAnswer: By giving no offence in anything
questions.explanation: Verse 3 instructs ministers to give no offence in anything so that the ministry is not blamed, promoting integrity and a blameless witness.

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged after facing many trials. What encouragement does 2 Corinthians 6 provide about life and death?
options: Though dying, we live; though chastened, we are not killed
Trials prove that God has abandoned us
Death ends all hope and rejoicing
Sorrow means God is displeased with us
questions.correctAnswer: Though dying, we live; though chastened, we are not killed
questions.explanation: Verse 9 explains that despite suffering and chastening, believers continue to live and persevere, showing God’s sustaining strength.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 6:14 teach about relationships and partnerships?
options: Do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers
Form partnerships without regard to faith
Only focus on financial gain in partnerships
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers
questions.explanation: Verse 14 warns against unequal yoking, emphasizing the incompatibility of righteousness with unrighteousness and light with darkness.

questions.question: How should believers respond to receiving God's grace according to 2 Corinthians 6?
options: Do not receive the grace of God in vain
Ignore the call to live righteously
Depend only on personal effort, not grace
questions.correctAnswer: Do not receive the grace of God in vain
questions.explanation: Verse 1 urges believers to receive God's grace meaningfully and not to waste or ignore it.

questions.question: What qualities does Paul list in 2 Corinthians 6:6 that believers should exhibit?
options: Pureness, knowledge, longsuffering, kindness, by the Holy Ghost, by love unfeigned
questions.correctAnswer: Pureness, knowledge, longsuffering, kindness, by the Holy Ghost, by love unfeigned
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes virtues believers should show as ministers of God, emphasizing character and spiritual fruit.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:16, what is the believer's identity in relation to God?
options: You are the temple of the living God
questions.correctAnswer: You are the temple of the living God
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that believers are God's temple, where He dwells and walks, signifying holiness and relationship.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 6:10 say about the paradox of the believer's condition?
options: As sorrowful yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, yet possessing all things
Always wealthy and never in need
Sorrowful with no hope for joy
questions.correctAnswer: As sorrowful yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, yet possessing all things
questions.explanation: Verse 10 presents the spiritual paradox believers experience, showing trust and contentment despite outward circumstances.

questions.question: What should believers do according to 2 Corinthians 6:17 to maintain holiness?
options: Come out from among them and be separate, and touch not the unclean thing
Blend in with the world to avoid conflict
Ignore purity and accept all things
Separate but continue to engage with unclean things
questions.correctAnswer: Come out from among them and be separate, and touch not the unclean thing
questions.explanation: Verse 17 calls believers to separation from impurity to maintain holiness and receive God's acceptance.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 6:18, God promises to be a Father to His people, making them His sons and daughters.
questions.explanation: Verse 18 clearly states God's promise to be a Father and that believers will be His sons and daughters.

questions.question: A believer feels constrained in their spiritual growth. Based on 2 Corinthians 6:11-13, what biblical encouragement would you offer?
options: Our hearts are enlarged toward you; be ye also enlarged
Spiritual growth is impossible for you
You are alone in your struggle
questions.correctAnswer: Our hearts are enlarged toward you; be ye also enlarged
questions.explanation: Verses 11-13 express openness and call the Corinthians to respond with an open and enlarged heart.

questions.question: What is the significance of not being 'unequally yoked' as taught in 2 Corinthians 6:14?
questions.explanation: Verse 14 teaches that righteousness and unrighteousness, light and darkness, have no true fellowship, highlighting spiritual incompatibility.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 6 describe the ministry experience in verse 5?
options: Stripes, imprisonments, tumults, labours, watchings, fastings
questions.correctAnswer: Stripes, imprisonments, tumults, labours, watchings, fastings
questions.explanation: Verse 5 lists the various hardships faced in ministry, emphasizing perseverance and dedication.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 6:8 teaches that ministers may face both honour and dishonour, evil report and good report.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 acknowledges the dual experiences of honour and dishonour, encouraging faithfulness despite circumstances.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 2 Corinthians 6:7 says believers are approved by the word of truth, by the power of God, and by the ______ of righteousness on the right hand and on the left.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 uses the metaphor of the 'armour of righteousness' to illustrate spiritual protection and readiness.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 6.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:2, Paul quotes a statement about the 'accepted time' and the 'day of salvation.' Which Old Testament book is this quotation most closely related to?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:2 quotes a phrase that closely aligns with Isaiah 49:8, which speaks of a 'time accepted' and a 'day of salvation,' linking Paul's message to the prophetic tradition.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:4-5, which of the following is NOT listed as a trial Paul endured for his ministry?
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 list afflictions including imprisonments, fastings, and tumults, but 'temptations' are not mentioned explicitly as a trial endured here.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in 2 Corinthians 6:8-10 where Paul contrasts opposing states such as 'honour and dishonour' and 'as poor, yet making many rich'?
questions.explanation: Paul uses antithesis in these verses to emphasize the paradoxes of Christian ministry, contrasting opposing experiences to illustrate the complexity of their calling.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:14, Paul warns against being 'unequally yoked' with unbelievers. This metaphor references what agricultural practice common in the ancient Near East?
options: Pairing oxen of different sizes to plow
questions.correctAnswer: Pairing oxen of different sizes to plow
questions.explanation: The 'unequally yoked' metaphor reflects the practice of pairing oxen of unequal strength for plowing, which would hinder work, symbolizing incompatible partnerships.

questions.question: Which Greek word translated as 'longsuffering' in 2 Corinthians 6:6 reflects the idea of patient endurance?
questions.explanation: 'Makrothumia' is the Greek term for longsuffering or patience, indicating steadfast endurance, as used in this verse to describe a quality of ministry.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:16, Paul refers to believers as 'the temple of the living God.' This concept corresponds with which Old Testament idea?
questions.explanation: Paul’s imagery echoes the Old Testament tabernacle where God dwelt among His people, now applied spiritually to believers as God’s temple.

questions.question: What is the primary theme emphasized in 2 Corinthians 6:1 about receiving grace?
options: Avoiding receiving God's grace in vain
Grace given only to the worthy
questions.correctAnswer: Avoiding receiving God's grace in vain
questions.explanation: Verse 1 encourages believers not to treat God's grace as ineffective or unproductive, urging a faithful response to divine favor.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:7, Paul mentions the 'armour of righteousness.' This phrase is most closely related to which Old Testament concept?
options: The armor of a Hebrew warrior
The clothing of the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: The armor of a Hebrew warrior
questions.explanation: Paul’s metaphor recalls the armor imagery familiar in the Old Testament and Near Eastern contexts, symbolizing spiritual protection and righteousness as defense.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:12, Paul uses a bodily metaphor to describe the Corinthians’ restraints. Which organ does he mention?
questions.explanation: Paul states 'ye are straitened in your own bowels,' using the term for inner affection or compassion, indicating emotional or spiritual constraint.

questions.question: In verse 17, Paul calls believers to 'come out from among them, and be ye separate.' This command is an allusion to which Old Testament passage?
questions.explanation: Leviticus 20:7 commands Israel to be holy and separate from unclean practices, which Paul recalls to urge separation from unbelievers.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Corinthians 6:10, Paul describes himself as 'having nothing, and yet possessing all things.'
questions.explanation: Verse 10 explicitly states this paradox, highlighting the spiritual riches that transcend material poverty.

questions.question: Which phrase in 2 Corinthians 6:15 contrasts Christ with a figure representing wickedness?
questions.explanation: Verse 15 contrasts Christ, representing holiness, with Belial, a term for wickedness or the devil, emphasizing incompatibility.

questions.question: In the context of 2 Corinthians 6, what is the significance of Paul addressing the Corinthians as 'workers together with him' in verse 1?
questions.explanation: Paul describes himself and the Corinthians as collaborators in God's work, stressing communal responsibility in the gospel.

questions.question: Which theme in 2 Corinthians 6 reflects a typology of the Old Testament concept of God's people as a holy nation set apart?
questions.explanation: The call to be 'separate' and 'not unequally yoked' reflects Israel’s status as a holy people distinct from surrounding nations.

questions.question: Which of the following is a theme in 2 Corinthians 6 emphasized by the repeated use of paradoxes like 'as dying, and, behold, we live'?
options: The suffering and resurrection reality of Christian ministry
questions.correctAnswer: The suffering and resurrection reality of Christian ministry
questions.explanation: The paradoxes highlight that despite suffering and apparent death, believers live through Christ’s power, a key theme in Pauline theology.

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:1, what is Paul urging believers not to receive in vain?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:1 exhorts believers to not receive the grace of God in vain. This aligns with Romans 6:1-2, where Paul warns against continuing in sin to receive more grace, and with Hebrews 12:15, which speaks about the grace of God that brings salvation.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:2, what phrase describes the timing of salvation?
options: The accepted time and the day of salvation
The appointed hour and the night of redemption
The eternal moment and the age of grace
The prophetic season and the day of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The accepted time and the day of salvation
questions.explanation: Paul quotes Isaiah 49:8 in 2 Corinthians 6:2, emphasizing that now is the accepted time and the day of salvation. This highlights the immediacy and availability of salvation, consistent with John 3:16 and 2 Peter 3:9.

questions.question: What attitude does Paul say ministers of God should maintain to avoid blame, according to 2 Corinthians 6:3?
options: Giving no offence in any thing
questions.correctAnswer: Giving no offence in any thing
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:3 calls ministers to give no offence so that the ministry is not blamed. This reflects Jesus' teaching in Matthew 5:13-16 about being a good example and avoiding causing others to stumble.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a hardship endured by Paul and his co-workers in 2 Corinthians 6:4-5?
questions.explanation: While Paul mentions stripes, imprisonments, tumults, labors, watchings, and fastings in 2 Corinthians 6:4-5, the specific term 'persecutions' is not used here. However, Acts 9:16 and 2 Timothy 3:12 confirm that persecution is a common experience for ministers of Christ.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:6, which of the following is a characteristic by which Paul approves himself as a minister?
questions.explanation: Paul lists kindness among other qualities such as pureness, knowledge, longsuffering, the Holy Ghost, and love unfeigned in 2 Corinthians 6:6. This reflects the fruit of the Spirit described in Galatians 5:22-23 and Christ's teaching in Ephesians 4:32.

questions.question: What spiritual 'armor' is mentioned in 2 Corinthians 6:7 as part of Paul's ministry?
options: The armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left
questions.correctAnswer: The armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:7 refers to the armour of righteousness on both hands, symbolizing active righteousness in ministry. This complements the full armor of God described in Ephesians 6:10-18, emphasizing righteousness as a key defensive and offensive tool.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:8, Paul describes experiencing both honor and dishonor. What paradox does he illustrate by this?
questions.explanation: Paul presents paradoxical realities of ministry in 2 Corinthians 6:8, such as being considered deceivers yet being truthful. This theme of suffering and vindication is echoed in Psalm 109:2-3 and 1 Peter 2:21-23.

questions.question: Which of the following contrasts is NOT mentioned in 2 Corinthians 6:9-10?
options: As dying, and, behold, we live
As poor, yet making many rich
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:9-10 includes contrasts like dying yet living, sorrowful yet rejoicing, and poor yet making many rich. The phrase 'powerful yet weak' is a Pauline theme found elsewhere (2 Corinthians 12:10), but not specifically listed here.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:11-13, Paul uses a metaphor about the Corinthians being 'straitened' or 'narrowed.' What does he imply they should do?
options: Be enlarged in heart and spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Be enlarged in heart and spirit
questions.explanation: Paul appeals to the Corinthians to be 'enlarged' as he speaks as to his children (2 Corinthians 6:13). This metaphor of openness contrasts their current 'straitened' state and aligns with Proverbs 18:24 and Philippians 4:12-13 regarding spiritual growth.

questions.question: What key prohibition does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 6:14 regarding relationships?
options: Be not unequally yoked together with unbelievers
Do not marry within your tribe
questions.correctAnswer: Be not unequally yoked together with unbelievers
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:14 warns against being unequally yoked with unbelievers, highlighting the incompatibility of righteousness and unrighteousness. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 22:10 and 1 Corinthians 15:33 about the influence of ungodly associations.

questions.question: Which two contrasting figures are mentioned in 2 Corinthians 6:15 to illustrate spiritual incompatibility?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:15 contrasts Christ with Belial (a term for wickedness or Satan), emphasizing no agreement between righteousness and evil. This dualism is echoed in 1 Samuel 17 and Romans 16:20 regarding Christ's victory over evil.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 6:16, believers are described as what?
options: The temple of the living God
questions.correctAnswer: The temple of the living God
questions.explanation: Paul calls believers the temple of the living God in 2 Corinthians 6:16, signifying God's indwelling presence. This reflects Old Testament imagery from Ezekiel 37:27 and New Testament teaching in 1 Corinthians 3:16 and John 14:23.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 6:17, what is the Lord’s command to believers concerning their separation from the world?
options: Come out from among them, and be ye separate, and touch not the unclean thing
Remain in the world but not of it
questions.correctAnswer: Come out from among them, and be ye separate, and touch not the unclean thing
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 6:17 quotes Old Testament calls for holiness (Isaiah 52:11; Ezekiel 20:34) urging believers to separate themselves from impurity. This is in harmony with Romans 12:2 and James 4:4 about not conforming to the world.

questions.question: What promise does God give to those who separate themselves as commanded in 2 Corinthians 6:18?
options: I will be a Father unto you, and ye shall be my sons and daughters
You shall reign with Christ forever
You shall be delivered from all trials
questions.correctAnswer: I will be a Father unto you, and ye shall be my sons and daughters
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 6:18, God promises to be a Father and to adopt believers as His sons and daughters. This echoes the covenant relationship in Exodus 4:22, Romans 8:14-17, and Galatians 4:6-7.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the theological emphasis of 2 Corinthians 6 regarding Christian ministry?
options: Suffering and righteousness in faithful service
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering and righteousness in faithful service
questions.explanation: Throughout 2 Corinthians 6, Paul presents ministry as marked by suffering (2 Corinthians 6:4-5) and righteous living (6:7-10). This reflects Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 10:24-25 and Peter’s call in 1 Peter 4:12-19 to endure suffering for righteousness’ sake.
